sourcesContent:
import React, { useState } from 'react'; const Kafka = () => { const [activeFlow, setActiveFlow] = useState(null); const [selectedService, setSelectedService] = useState(null); const [activeTab, setActiveTab] = useState('overview'); const [showEventStructure, setShowEventStructure] = useState(false); // Theory sections const theoryTabs = [ { id: 'overview', label: 'Kafka Overview' }, { id: 'architecture', label: 'Architecture' }, { id: 'flow', label: 'E-commerce Flow' }, { id: 'implementation', label: 'Implementation' } ]; const theoryContent = { overview: (

Kafka in E-commerce Systems

In the e-commerce system, various services like Order Service, Payment Service, Inventory Service, Notification Service, and Shipping Service use Kafka to send and receive messages asynchronously. Kafka enables event-driven communication between services, ensuring loose coupling, scalability, and fault tolerance.

Key Benefits

  • Loose Coupling: Services communicate via events without direct dependencies
  • Scalability: Each service can be scaled independently based on load
  • Fault Tolerance: Messages are persisted and can be replayed if services fail
  • Real-time Processing: Events are processed as they occur
), architecture: (

Kafka Architecture in E-commerce

Kafka's pub-sub architecture with producers, topics, and consumers

Topics & Partitions

Topics are categories for events (e.g., order-events). Each topic is split into partitions for parallelism.

Common E-commerce Topics:
  • • order-events: OrderPlaced, OrderCancelled
  • • payment-events: PaymentProcessed, PaymentFailed
  • • inventory-events: StockUpdated, OutOfStock
  • • shipping-events: ShipmentInitiated, ShipmentDelivered
  • • notification-events: EmailSent, SMSSent

Producers & Consumers

Services act as producers (publishing events) and consumers (processing events).

Producers:
  • • Order Service → order-events
  • • Payment Service → payment-events
  • • Shipping Service → shipping-events
Consumers:
  • • Payment Service ← order-events
  • • Shipping Service ← payment-events
  • • Notification ← multiple topics
), flow: (

Kafka Event Processing Flow

1. Placing an Order

1
Order Service

Creates a new order and sends an OrderPlaced event to order-events topic

{showEventStructure && ( 
{`{
  "eventId": "evt_12345",
  "eventType": "OrderPlaced",
  "timestamp": "2025-05-23T10:30:00Z",
  "orderId": "12345",
  "customerId": "789",
  "items": [
    {"productId": "prod-1", "quantity": 2, "price": 50.00},
    {"productId": "prod-2", "quantity": 1, "price": 50.50}
  ],
  "totalAmount": 100.50,
  "status": "PLACED"
}`}
)}
2
Payment Service

Consumes OrderPlaced event, processes payment, and sends PaymentProcessed to payment-events

3
Inventory Service

Consumes OrderPlaced event and updates product stock

4
Shipping Service

Consumes PaymentProcessed event and initiates shipment

5
Notification Service

Consumes multiple events and sends notifications to customers

Service Responsibilities

  • Order Service: Creates orders → publishes OrderPlaced → order-events
  • Payment Service: Consumes OrderPlaced → processes payment → publishes PaymentProcessed
  • Inventory Service: Consumes OrderPlaced → updates stock → publishes InventoryUpdated

Event Flow

Order Service → order-events
↳ Payment Service → payment-events
↳ Inventory Service → inventory-events
↳ Shipping Service → shipping-events
↳ Notification Service consumes all
), implementation: (

Service Implementation Details

Order Service

Acts as Kafka producer when an order is placed. Publishes OrderPlaced events. 

{`@Service
public class OrderService {
  private final KafkaTemplate kafkaTemplate;

  public void placeOrder(Order order) {
    OrderPlacedEvent event = new OrderPlacedEvent(
      UUID.randomUUID().toString(),
      "OrderPlaced",
      Instant.now(),
      order.getId(),
      order
    );
    
    kafkaTemplate.send("order-events", order.getId(), event);
  }
}`}

Payment Service

Consumes OrderPlaced events, processes payments, and publishes PaymentProcessed events. 

{`@Service
public class PaymentService {
  @KafkaListener(topics = "order-events", groupId = "payment-group")
  public void processOrderEvent(OrderPlacedEvent event) {
    Payment payment = processPayment(event);
    PaymentProcessedEvent paymentEvent = new PaymentProcessedEvent(
      payment.getId(),
      payment.getStatus()
    );
    kafkaTemplate.send("payment-events", payment.getId(), paymentEvent);
  }
}`}

Inventory Service

Consumes OrderPlaced events and updates product stock. 

{`@KafkaListener(topics = "order-events", groupId = "inventory-group")
public void updateInventory(OrderPlacedEvent event) {
  event.getItems().forEach(item -> {
    inventoryRepository.decreaseStock(
      item.getProductId(), 
      item.getQuantity()
    );
  });
}`}

Shipping Service

Consumes PaymentProcessed events and initiates shipments. 

{`@KafkaListener(topics = "payment-events", groupId = "shipping-group")
public void initiateShipping(PaymentProcessedEvent event) {
  if (event.getStatus() == "COMPLETED") {
    Shipment shipment = shippingService.createShipment(event.getOrderId());
    kafkaTemplate.send("shipping-events", shipment.toEvent());
  }
}`}
) }; // E-commerce example data const services = [ { name: 'Order Service', role: 'Producer', description: 'Creates orders and publishes OrderPlaced events to order-events topic', topics: { produces: ['order-events'], consumes: [] }, color: 'bg-blue-100 border-blue-300', codeExample: `kafkaTemplate.send("order-events", orderEvent);` }, { name: 'Payment Service', role: 'Producer/Consumer', description: 'Processes payments (consumes order-events) and publishes PaymentProcessed events', topics: { produces: ['payment-events'], consumes: ['order-events'] }, color: 'bg-green-100 border-green-300', codeExample: `@KafkaListener(topics = "order-events")\npublic void processPayment(OrderEvent event) {...}` }, { name: 'Inventory Service', role: 'Consumer', description: 'Updates stock levels when consuming OrderPlaced events', topics: { produces: [], consumes: ['order-events'] }, color: 'bg-yellow-100 border-yellow-300', codeExample: `@KafkaListener(topics = "order-events")\npublic void updateStock(OrderEvent event) {...}` }, { name: 'Shipping Service', role: 'Producer/Consumer', description: 'Initiates shipments (consumes payment-events) and publishes shipping events', topics: { produces: ['shipping-events'], consumes: ['payment-events'] }, color: 'bg-purple-100 border-purple-300', codeExample: `@KafkaListener(topics = "payment-events")\npublic void shipOrder(PaymentEvent event) {...}` }, { name: 'Notification Service', role: 'Consumer', description: 'Listens to multiple topics and sends customer notifications', topics: { produces: [], consumes: ['order-events', 'payment-events', 'shipping-events'] }, color: 'bg-pink-100 border-pink-300', codeExample: `@KafkaListener(topics = {"order-events", "payment-events"})\npublic void notifyCustomer(Event event) {...}` } ]; const topics = [ { name: 'order-events', events: ['OrderPlaced', 'OrderCancelled'], color: 'bg-blue-50', description: 'Contains all order-related events. Consumed by Payment, Inventory, and Notification services.' }, { name: 'payment-events', events: ['PaymentProcessed', 'PaymentFailed'], color: 'bg-green-50', description: 'Contains payment status events. Consumed by Shipping and Notification services.' }, { name: 'inventory-events', events: ['StockUpdated', 'OutOfStock'], color: 'bg-yellow-50', description: 'Contains inventory updates. Could be consumed by Notification or Dashboard services.' }, { name: 'shipping-events', events: ['ShipmentInitiated', 'ShipmentDelivered'], color: 'bg-purple-50', description: 'Contains shipping status updates. Consumed by Notification service.' }, { name: 'notification-events', events: ['EmailSent', 'SMSSent'], color: 'bg-pink-50', description: 'Contains notification confirmations. Could be consumed by Audit service.' } ]; const flowSteps = [ { step: 1, service: 'Order Service', action: 'Customer places order → OrderPlaced event sent to order-events topic', eventExample: { eventType: 'OrderPlaced', orderId: '12345', customerId: '789', items: ['prod-1', 'prod-2'], total: 100.50 } }, { step: 2, service: 'Payment Service', action: 'Consumes OrderPlaced → Processes payment → Sends PaymentProcessed to payment-events', eventExample: { eventType: 'PaymentProcessed', orderId: '12345', amount: 100.50, status: 'COMPLETED' } }, { step: 3, service: 'Inventory Service', action: 'Consumes OrderPlaced → Updates stock → Sends InventoryUpdated to inventory-events', eventExample: { eventType: 'StockUpdated', productId: 'prod-1', newQuantity: 95 } }, { step: 4, service: 'Shipping Service', action: 'Consumes PaymentProcessed → Initiates shipment → Sends ShipmentInitiated to shipping-events', eventExample: { eventType: 'ShipmentInitiated', orderId: '12345', trackingNumber: 'TN12345678' } }, { step: 5, service: 'Notification Service', action: 'Consumes multiple events → Sends notifications → Publishes EmailSent/SMSSent', eventExample: { eventType: 'EmailSent', orderId: '12345', emailType: 'ORDER_CONFIRMATION' } } ]; const handleFlowDemo = () => { setActiveFlow(0); flowSteps.forEach((_, index) => { setTimeout(() => { setActiveFlow(index); }, index * 1500); }); setTimeout(() => { setActiveFlow(null); }, flowSteps.length * 1500); }; return (

Kafka in E-commerce Architecture

Implementing event-driven microservices with Apache Kafka for order processing

Complete Event Structure

{`// Base Event Structure
public abstract class BaseEvent {
  private String eventId;
  private String eventType;
  private Instant timestamp;
  private String aggregateId;
  private Map metadata;
  
  // Constructors, getters, setters
}

// OrderPlaced Event Example
public class OrderPlacedEvent extends BaseEvent {
  private String orderId;
  private String customerId;
  private List items;
  private BigDecimal totalAmount;
  private String status;
  
  // Constructors, getters, setters
}`}
{/* Best Practices Section */}

Kafka Best Practices

Schema Design

  • • Use Avro/Protobuf with Schema Registry
  • • Design backward/forward compatible schemas
  • • Include standard metadata in all events

Consumer Design

  • • Implement idempotent processing
  • • Handle retries and dead-letter topics
  • • Monitor consumer lag

Producer Design

  • • Configure appropriate acks (1/all)
  • • Implement retries with backoff
  • • Use key-based partitioning carefully

Error Handling

  • • Implement dead-letter queues
  • • Log failed events for debugging
  • • Consider retry topics for transient failures

Monitoring

  • • Track end-to-end latency
  • • Monitor consumer lag
  • • Alert on delivery failures

Security

  • • Enable SSL encryption
  • • Use SASL authentication
  • • Implement ACLs for topic access
); }; export default Kafka;
